title: Package renaming in mirrors.
body:
When using spack on a machine that does not have internet access the mapping of package names from those downloaded to the mirror is not always 1:1.

For example.

```
==> Installing lcms
==> Fetching file:///home/Role.Apps/src/lcms/lcms-2.8.tar.gz
curl: (37) Couldn't open file /home/Role.Apps/src/lcms/lcms-2.8.tar.gz
==> Fetching from file:///home/Role.Apps/src/lcms/lcms-2.8.tar.gz failed.
==> Fetching http://downloads.sourceforge.net/project/lcms/lcms/2.8/lcms2-2.8.tar.gz
```

Here the package name that gets downloaded is `lcms2-2.8.tar.gz`. However it is looking in the off-line (local disk) mirror for `lcms-2.8.tar.gz`.

Other examples are**libtiff**,

```
==> Fetching file:///home/Role.Apps/src/libtiff/libtiff-4.0.7.tar.gz
curl: (37) Couldn't open file /home/Role.Apps/src/libtiff/libtiff-4.0.7.tar.gz
==> Fetching from file:///home/Role.Apps/src/libtiff/libtiff-4.0.7.tar.gz failed.
==> Fetching http://download.osgeo.org/libtiff/tiff-4.0.7.tar.gz
```

**Grib-API**: `grib_api-1.21.0-Source.tar.gz` (download) vs `grib-api-1.21.0.tar.gz` (local mirror).

This is also true for **wgrib2**, which has an even crazier online/download name of `wgrib2.tgz.v2.0.6c`, then mirror is expecting `wgrib2-2.0.6c.tar.gz`. 

In the case of Ruby gems, #3127, stalled as I couldn't get around the `.None` suffix.

Is this non-easily download, xfer/sync meant to work and does `spack mirror ...` work instead?
